en: Interview with Sheila Grooms, 2020-06-19

Interview with Sheila Grooms, respiratory therapist with LeConte Medical Center, conducted by Ken Wise. Grooms discusses the assistance she provided to victims of the fire at the medical center and also while volunteering at Rocky Top Sports World. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "We were prepared, we evacuated some of the higher acuity patients just because, one, like I said, smoke irritates the lungs anyway. So we were making sure our people that had very compromised lungs were out. But no, we never had to evacuate the hospital."

This is a representative quote from the interview: "We were prepared, we evacuated some of the higher acuity patients just because, one, like I said, smoke irritates the lungs anyway. Interview with Sheila Grooms, 2020-06-19 -- Sevierville
Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Sheila Grooms, 2020-06-19
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and what organization you are affiliated with?
How hong have you been working in Sevierville?
What do you do at the LeConte Medical Center?
When did you first become aware of the fire on the Chimney Tops?
Was there any concern initially that this fire was different from previous ones?
What road were you coming into Sevierville on?
What did the fire look like on your way in?
Was this the evening just before the fire went into Gatlinburg or the the evening after?
When you got to work, what was transpiring there?
What were you and you colleagues anticipating?
As you were preparing, when did you realize that things were not what you expected?
What types of injuries were coming into the hospital when the firetrucks and helicopters arrived?
Can you describe what you saw and how you felt? What made the image of that sky stick with you?
What time was it when you went out and saw all the equipment and vehicles?
Can you describe what happened when the emergency vehicles began to bring in patients?
Why were you scared when these patients were coming in? Can you describe how you were feeling?
What kind of volume were you seeing that night?
What kind of anxiety or anticipation were you feeling?
Did the patients keep coming through the whole night?
Are there any specific memories from that night that still stand out to you?
What else happened that night after communications started to go down?
Where is the hospital located in relation to more prominent landmarks?
What was driving some of the rumors while the communications were down?
What was driving some of the rumors while the communications were down?
What attempts did you make to get in contact with your family? what failed?
What transpires as you get further into the night?
Was it just the Park Vista that calls were coming from, or all of Gatliburg?
How did you respond when a call comes in from an elderly couple in an elevator?
Did you stay on the phone with this couple until help arrived at the scene?
Did you ever have to evacuate the hospital?
What was the reaction at the hospital immediately after the fire?
What did you see when you first went into Rocky Top the day after the fire?
What were you doing at Rocky Top?
Can you describe what the after effects looked like? What made it so scary?
What was it like dealing with an epileptic patient, while there is a crowd surrounding you?
What kind of injuries were you seeing on the first responders?
How would you assess the short-term relief efforts you witnessed at Rocky Top?
Did the Red Cross and volunteers handle these efforts well?
Was this response similar to that of the hospital where you work?
Was there anything about the whole fire event that was surprising?
You encountered several people in trouble during this time, did you follow up with any of these patients afterwards?
What emotional impact did this event have on you?
Was there anything good that came out of this fire event?
Did you have the chance to see how this event affected community relations in Gatlinburg?
Is there anything else that you would like to share?
As a respiratory therapist, how was dealing with victims from the wildfires similar to the current corona virus?
Are you seeing tourists or locals with COVID-19?
